Award.AwardTitle: Small Business ERC Collaborative Opportunity to Develop a Biomass Conversion to Fatty Acids Platform

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research and development work at the NSF Engineering Research Center for biorenewable Chemicals (CBiRC) has identified a bio-process for conversion of sugars to fatty acids as a platform technology. The fatty acid synthesis pathway can serve as an extremely versatile platform for the production of a very diverse class of chemicals. Due to rising demand and constrained supply, fatty acids are currently produced from palm or coconut oils. Due to rising demand and constrained supply, fatty acid prices have quadrupled in the last decade and are projected to rise further. The proposed effort will enable a broad platform for commercialization of various biomass-derived fatty acids and their derived products. Such a platform will cater to many industry sectors including consumer products, nutrition, personal care and polymers based upon carbon chain length of the fatty acids. The proposed effort will focus upon commercialization of C14 and C16 fatty acids. Technology Holding LLC (small business) and Rice University (CBiRC) have collaborated to develop and commercialize the patent-protected biomass conversion to fatty acids and fatty acid derivatives platform.

The proposed process utilizes patent-pending metabolically engineered E. Coli culture to convert C6 sugars from biomass to fatty acids. The metabolically engineered strains have shown to exhibit extremely promising performance - these strains can produce fatty acids at a fatty acids/glucose yield close to the maximum theoretical value and at good production rate. The goal of the proposed collaboration is to translate the existing ERC platform research into the marketplace by developing a hierarchy of fatty acid and derivative products synthesis based upon yield and market price. The commercialization effort will focus upon: (1) Demonstrating the intellectual property protected fatty acid based platform technology via scale-up; (2) Rapidly transitioning the fatty acid based platform technology to the marketplace aligned with the translational goal of CBiRC and (3) Creating an economically viable product portfolio from the platform.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Current support helped to develop technology for converting biomass in to free fatty acids. During this collaborative project between Technology Holding LLC and Rice Univeristy, new university-industry collboration has been culminated into novel technology development. New strains were developed for production free fatty acids preferentially myristic acid. Novel microbial strain developed during this project period showed more robust performance with biomass hydrolysate. The microbial free fatty acids production technology was successfully scaled-up from laboratory scale to bench scale in the industry set-up. Techno-economic analysis performed for this process showed feasibility at larger scale. Completion of this project developed integrated platform for production of free fatty acids from biomass to the final product. This funded project provided traiining opportunity to the 3 postdoctorate students and 1 undergraduate student. The new knowledge generated during this project period will accelerate the development of microbial free fatty acid based consumer and advanced fuel industry. The results of this project deonstrated feasibility of lignocellulose based technologies for chemicals and other products. Also, this project helped to advocate, renewable and sustainable production e.g. current activity showed potential for global ecological balance and reduction of rainforest destruction.  The results successfully demonstrated possibility of growth of biomass industry in rural area and creating new jobs. 


Last Modified: 11/05/2015
Modified by: Mukund Karanjikar
